title: 105_s494
content: The Act is titled the "Federal Prisoner Health Care Copayment Act" and it includes provisions for prisoner copayments for health care services. The "Federal Prisoner Health Care Copayment Act" amends Chapter 303 of title 18, United States Code, by adding a section on prisoner copayments for health care services. It defines terms like account, Director, health care provider, health care visit, and prisoner. The "Federal Prisoner Health Care Copayment Act" defines terms like prisoner, qualified health care visit, and outlines exceptions for health care visits. The "Federal Prisoner Health Care Copayment Act" outlines exceptions for health care visits, including annual examinations, emergency visits, immunizations, visits initiated by Bureau of Prisons staff, referrals by prison officials, and visits by prisoners under 18, pregnant, mentally ill, or disabled. The Director is responsible for determining copayments for health care services. The Director of the Bureau of Prisons assesses and collects copayments for health care services, including fees for health care visits and prescription medications provided to prisoners. The fees range from $3 to $5 for each qualified health care visit and not more than $5 for prescription medications. Additionally, fees are established for health care visits resulting from serious mental illness or permanent disability. The Director of the Bureau of Prisons assesses and collects copayments for health care services provided to prisoners. Fees are charged for health care visits related to injuries inflicted by other prisoners, with payment responsibility falling on the prisoner receiving the care or the one causing the injury. Fees must be paid on the date of the health care visit. The Director of the Bureau of Prisons assesses and collects copayments for health care services provided to prisoners. Fees are charged for health care visits related to injuries inflicted by other prisoners, with payment responsibility falling on the prisoner receiving the care or the one causing the injury. Fees must be paid on the date of the health care visit, or through an installment payment plan if the prisoner's account balance is insufficient. Treatment cannot be refused based on financial reasons. The Director of the Bureau of Prisons collects copayments for health care services provided to prisoners who are unable to pay due to insolvency or financial constraints. Amounts collected are deposited into the Crime Victims' Fund. The Director must report annually to Congress on the amounts collected and the impact on prisoners' health care visits.
